detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
This course is intended for students in their final year (4th or 5th).
If you are an engineering student in: Civil and Geological engineering you will take CIVL 402; Biomedical engineering you will take BMEG 455; Manufacturing engineering you will take MECH 400.
If you are in year 3 and are interested in this course, please register on the waitlist.
If you are unable to register in this course directly, please register on the waitlist and we will be reviewing your registration. Graduating students will have priority registration from the waitlist.
If you have any questions, please contact EAS. Please do not contact the instructor. 

Please use the UBC Directory to find your instructor/TA contact information.

instances.text: ARBM_V 450-011 - Advanced Studies in Modern Arabic Language and Cultures

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
Delivery Mode -This is an in-person course. Students are expected to meet in-person on the days and times listed. All courses labelled as ‘in-person’ are fully in-person for the entire term, including exams, and require in-person attendance to complete.

Waitlist Policy -All waitlists will follow a first come, first serve policy, unless specified otherwise. Once a course is full, its status will be changed to “Waitlist” and students who register will be automatically added to the waitlist.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: Maps offer far more than an objective representation of a stable human reality. They can orient, delineate, historicise, conceal, challenge, persuade, and even misrepresent, social and scientific research. This course introduces students to current methods of mapping archaeological information, and will cast a critical and reflexive gaze on spatial theories and practices within the broader domain of anthropology. Students will have opportunities in this course to experiment with a variety of mapping tools through guided lab exercises, and throughout the term will work to complete an independent lab that showcases their newly acquired analytical toolkit.

instances.text: ARTH_V 432-001 - Seminar in the Art of the Middle Ages

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: The pre-modern Eurasian continent has been influenced by cross-cultural contact since ancient times. The Silk Roads stand out as the most prominent representation of these extensive cultural interactions. This course introduces the history of the Silk Roads during the Middle Ages through artifacts, buildings, and narratives. it explores how this network of long-distance trade routes facilitated the transmission of ideas, forms, and meanings among diverse cultural groups across Eurasia.

instances.text: ARTH_V 450-001 - Seminar in Art in the Islamic World

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: How can you sleep when you’re certain that the nightmare demon will visit you? What does it mean to live in a world where images of dragons protected buildings? And what happens when a sultan issues a fatwa to combat vampires? This course explores monsters, and the art of the occult in the Islamic World, by situating them in the broader context of “Monster Studies.” Inspired by the works of Donna Haraway and Jeffrey Cohen, the course appreciates the monster as the ultimate expression of difference and challenges all binaries, whether pertaining to art history, or to societal norms.

instances.text: ARTH_V 476-001 - Seminar in North American Indigenous Art

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
ARTH 476
Seminar in North American Indigenous Art: Art vs. Artifact and the Role of Historical Indigenous Material Culture 
Historical Indigenous material culture occupies a fraught position within the art world. Native masks, tools, regalia, ceramics, and weavings are often categorized in contemporary society as “art,” although these items possess important socio-economic, religious, cultural, political, and gendered meanings, as well. Utilizing MOA’s collections and using case studies from across Canada and the United States, this course examines Native art beyond the realm of aesthetics or visuality and instead considers the original cultural significance and intended purpose of historical objects. Lectures, discussions, and fieldtrips explore Indigenous-made objects of the pre- and early colonial periods, with students learning how to conduct original research on objects, archives, and collections. Readings, presentations, and assignments address timely questions related to Indigenous art of the past and present, including: What obstacles arise when art is disconnected from its cultural context?, What are the consequences of displaying historical Indigenous items in galleries and museums?, and, What role did collectors, curators, and artists play in transforming everyday objects into highly desirable artistic masterpieces? 

(Note: This course is discussion and participation based, with grades relying heavily upon attending class/fieldtrips and presenting your work in front of peers.)

instances.text: ASIA_V 433-011 - Representations of Muslims in Hindi/Urdu Films

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
Delivery Mode -This is a mixed online course, it includes both synchronous and asynchronous components. Students are expected to meet online using Zoom on the days and times listed, as well as complete supplemental asynchronous work outside of class time. Please refer to the course syllabus for details on the asynchronous elements of this course. All courses labelled as ‘online’ are fully online for the entire term, including exams, and do NOT require any in-person attendance to complete.
Waitlist Policy -All waitlists will follow a first come, first serve policy, unless specified otherwise. Once a course is full, its status will be changed to “Waitlist” and students who register will be automatically added to the waitlist.

uiLabels.WDRES.FACETEDSEARCH.SymanSyntax:
Boolean logic can be expressed using AND, OR, NOT, and (). 
Exact phrases can be surrounded by double quotation marks. 
Example: ("software engineer" OR computer science) AND ~manager~.
